title: Nancy Kerrigan to play princess, vampire queen in 'Halloween on Ice'
text:
SYRACUSE, N.Y. -- Nancy Kerrigan's Halloween On Ice , a 15-city tour, comes to the Oncenter War Memorial Arena on Thursday, Oct. 15.
The tour kicked off on Oct. 8 in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and Syracuse will be the fifth stop for Kerrigan and the cast of skating champions, which includes Johnny Weir, Kurt Browning, Alissa Czisny, Nicole Bobek and Jozef Sabovcik.
The routine tells a spooky, kid-friendly Halloween tale with skating, music, wild costumes and moving scenery.
Two-time Olympic medalist Kerrigan said the first production of "Halloween On Ice" debuted in 1995, just before she was pregnant with her first son, Matthew.
The tradition has extended for 20 years, but never with the same characters and scenes.
"That's the beauty of Halloween," said Kerrigan in an Oct. 10 interview with syracuse.com. "We can keep recreating the story. Some [stories] are little more gory and scary while others are more sweet and cute."
Kerrigan describes this year's show is similar to "The Nutcracker," erring on the "sweet and cute" end of the spectrum of supernatural stories.
"My character starts as an old woman who falls asleep in a chair and wakes up magically in a complete different costume, as a princess," Kerrigan said. "The pink princess turns into a vampire queen by the end of Act One."
Kerrigan's oldest son, Matthew, designed all her costumes and the attire of the witches in the show. All the costume changes take place right on the ice.
"People are like, 'How did that happen?'" Kerrigan said. "Even a few weeks ago, Kurt [Browning] kept asking how we were going to do this. I'm just wearing a lot of layers."
Kerrigan's costumes won't be the only jaw-droppers on the ice. On Oct. 8, three-time U.S. national skating champion Johnny Weir shared a look at his "Halloween on Ice" costume (below). Something tells us his character may be responsible for the Kerrigan's transition into a vampire queen.
And so it begins...@halloweenonice Opening Night! #bloodymary
A photo posted by JOHNNY WEIR (@johnnygweir) on Oct 8, 2015 at 3:59pm PDT
Kerrigan remembers the 1996 "Halloween on Ice" had a "bad" effect on the younger audiences. About 24 glow-in-the-dark skeletons came out to Kerrigan from under a bed.
"It wasn't bloody or gory, but kids were crying," she said. "We decided that's not what we want to do. Some parents love it, but we can do Halloween story lines without having to be scary."
Kerrigan can relate to concerned parents. She says the hardest part of being on tour is being away from her younger kids, and figuring out who's going to drive them to their gymnastics and ballet practices at home. (Her children Brian, 10, and Nicole, 7, will travel to see her "Halloween on Ice" performance next weekend.)
"They have their own stuff," Kerrigan said. "I can't let my things make their life stop. Typically, I'm at home driving them around. People ask, 'Why don't you coach [skating]?' If I were to do that, then I couldn't be there for my own kids."
At home, Kerrigan's Olympic medals aren't on display. She keeps them in a travel bag to bring to events so young people can see them. On Thursday, there will be a post show meet-and-greet for skating fans to meet the stars.
"It's been a while since I've been back to Syracuse but I liked it there and I'm looking forward to coming back," Kerrigan said.
Nancy Kerrigan's Halloween On Ice
Where: The Oncenter War Memorial Arena, Syracuse, NY
When: Thursday, Oct. 15 at 7 p.m.
How much: Tickets range from $25 to $85 and are on sale via Ticketmaster.com, by phone at 800-745-3000 or at the Solvay Bank Box Office at the Oncenter. Meet-and-greet tickets are available for $75.
